Microsoft Corp CEO Steve Ballmer identified "better global enforcement of intellectual property laws" as the world's largest software company's No. 1 lobbying priority in an interview with the Washington Post in July. That is particularly true in China, where the protections are the weakest, Steve Ballmer told the paper. US businesses' fears range from outright piracy of their goods to the transfer of technological know-how that can be inevitable in joint ventures with Chinese companies. "Sometimes Beijing

murky truth will come to light." Mr Andy Coulson is understood to have told the Prime Minister of his intention to resign on Wednesday but the decision was announced on Friday. 22 Jan 2011 I stand by what I've said about those events but when the spokesman needs a spokesman it's time to move on, he added. The Prime Minister said he was "very sorry" Mr Andy Coulson felt "compelled" to go after months of intense pressure, insisting he was being "punished for the same offence twice

." As Page takes on the day-to-day operations and the legal responsibilities associated with the title of CEO, Eric Schmidt will remain involved as the Executive Chairmen. According to Google, his new responsibilities will involve focusing externally on deals, partnerships, customers and broader business relationships, government outreach and technology thought leadership-all of which are increasingly important given Google's global reach. Eric Schmidt will also continue to act as an advisor to Page and Sergey Brin . Sergey Brin will continue to work with Google's philanthropic division on energy and climate change projects, and will be involved with all new

What Yahoo is to Bing, Nokia is to Windows Phone 7. "The game has changed from a war of devices to a war of ecosystems," said Nokia CEO Stephen Elop at his press conference. We have an opportunity to disrupt the trajectory in the mobile ecosystem. Together we will deliver great mobile products. Steve Ballmer said Microsoft and Nokia "can work together in a different kind of a way." Nokia and Microsoft engineers will collaborate.
